title: Sick of the British summer? Then sail away with these amazing pictures of ships at sea
text:
View
comments
The British summer has been something of a washout this year - but these incredible pictures of ships at sea around the world will soon help you forget.
They've been taken by professional sailing photographer Kurt Arrigo, from Malta, who has battled raging seas, dangled out of helicopters and stayed up for 30 to 40 hours to get the perfect shot.
The award-winning snapper, who is regularly commissioned for Rolex-sponsored races, described how the unpredictable nature of seas presents him with a constant challenge.
Professional sailing photographer Kurt Arrigo travels the world capturing some of the most exciting yachting events in the business
Mounting the camera to the front of a boat allowed for a eye-catching perspective
A dramatic aerial shot over a race in Barcelona in 2011 shows a multitude of yachts streaming across the seas
The award-winning snapper is regularly commissioned for Rolex-sponsored races. Pictured is a dramatic sunset behind two boats in a race
'Sailing photographers have to expect the unexpected, and be prepared for whatever challenges unfold before your eyes,' Arrigo told MailOnline Travel.
'A lot of preparation goes into each event, but you are constantly tested by the sea and elements which are continually moving.'
Becoming a sailing photographer was a natural move for the 46-year-old from Malta because as a teenager he raced in windsurfing and sailing competitions.
He received his first camera from his grandfather when he was 11 and when he was 15 he started taking it on his escapades.
 Next The traveller who quit studying to visit 97 countries by the... Getting away from it all... in 1948: The fascinating... The spectacular hotels of the future: Amazing designs... Arrigo now travels around the world, tasked with capturing some of the most spectacular and exciting races.
But while it's his name on the picture credit, what you see is the result of team work and a variety of methods, including using helicopters and drones for spectacular aerial shots.
'I have to communicate with the helicopter or boat crew to ensure I get the shot, it's a collaboration,' he said.
Bird's eye view: Arrigo uses drones and helicopters to capture amazing perspectives of boats
A large group of sailing boats bob in the shining sea as part of the 2013 Rolex Fastnet fleet in the Solent
A shining sea: Arrigo received his first camera from his grandfather when he was 11 but it was only when he was 15 that he started taking it on his escapades
'The ocean is alive and constantly shifting so you can never get the same shot again,' said Arrigo. Pictured is the Rolex Middle Sea Race in 2009
Of course what steals the show in most of the pictures is the raging elements surrounding the boats.
'From sunrise to sunset the sea and skies constantly provide dramatic moods for the pictures,' Arrigo commented.
'The ocean is alive and constantly shifting so you can never get the same shot again. Sometimes you will spend ages waiting for the perfect picture, and at others, you will only have a few seconds.'
In the action: A crew man a large yacht in the Gozo weekend regatta by Global Capital
Here Arrigo captured a lone yacht perfectly framed by a tunnel in a large rock
On your marks: A multitude of white-coloured yachts await the start of a race in Barcelona in 2011
What steals the show in most of the pictures is the raging ocean beneath the boats, as shown by this close-up shot
But while Arrigo has dabbled with drones he admits he prefers holding a camera in his hands because you can continually swap the lens for a different focus.
In his role as an official sailing photographer he has captured some iconic moments from international classics like the Rolex Sydney Hobart and the bi-annual Rolex Fastnet.
The latter event this year, on August 16- 23, involved 300 yachts racing over 600 miles over five days battling the wind and tricky tidal conditions.
Arrigo has dabbled with drones to get aerial shots but admits he prefers having a camera in his hand. Pictured: Strombolicchio in the Aeolian Islands of Italy
A contrast of dark ships against a shining sea make for a captivating image
Taking to the water was second nature for Arrigo, who raced in windsurfing and sailing competitions when he was a teenager. Pictured is a Velsheda yacht
After years of dedication Arrigo now travels around the world tasked with capturing some of the most spectacular and exciting races. Pictured is a boat rounding Fastnet Rock in front of a spectacular sunrise
Racers headed down the Solent, past major south coast headlands before turning round Fastnet rock and returning via the Scilly Isles before finishing at Plymouth.
'The most important thing I was told when I started out in sailing photographer is to enjoy it and have a sense of humour,' he said.
'If you have a passion for what you are doing this energy will be shown in your pictures.'
For those keen on a career in niche photography, Arrigo recommends building a portfolio of pictures that stand out.
Drawing inspiration from other photographers will also up the standard, he added.
Next he heads to San Francisco for the Rolex Big Boats Series on September 17-20.
The 2015 Rolex Fastnet converging at The Needles shortly after the race start. In the race boats headed down the Solent, past major south coast headlands before turning round Fastnet rock and returning via the Scilly Isles before finishing at Plymouth
His role as an official sailing photographer has resulted in iconic moments from international classics like the Rolex Sydney Hobart (pictured in 2009)
Sometimes less is more, as this stunning picture of a lone yacht against brooding clouds shows
A close-up shot showing the crew manning their vessel in the middle of the Rolex Middle Sea Race in 2009
A lone yacht tackles the large waves as part of the Rolex Middle Sea Race in 2009
Arrigo recommends that those who want a career in niche photography should build up a portfolio of work
A fleet of three colourful boats passing the Stromboli as part of the recent bi-annual Rolex Fastnet event, on August 16- 23, which involved 300 yachts racing over 600 miles over five days battling the wind and tricky tidal conditions
